content.body:
Ah, that doesn't sound unreasonable.

I was thinking some more about overloading `append()` just to see if I missed something in rejecting it and I'm not sure that it really works apart from the issues already identified. In particular when you pass multiple arguments to `append()` the complexity is increased pretty rapidly and you would definitely get different mutation records if you attempted to handle that as multiple moves or some such. Which you would not always be able to do and thus you'd need careful bookkeeping as well. Seems way too messy compared with "new primitive, new method".
content.formatted_body:
Ah, that doesn't sound unreasonable.

I was thinking some more about overloading append() just to see if I missed something in rejecting it and I'm not sure that it really works apart from the issues already identified. In particular when you pass multiple arguments to append() the complexity is increased pretty rapidly and you would definitely get different mutation records if you attempted to handle that as multiple moves or some such. Which you would not always be able to do and thus you'd need careful bookkeeping as well. Seems way too messy compared with "new primitive, new method".

content.body: My impression with "good first issue" continues to be that we put more time into marking new comments as spam than it would take us to fix the issue. Now of course the whole idea is that we don't fix the issue so someone gets the opportunity to ease into contributing, but still.

> <@annevk:matrix.org> Ah, that doesn't sound unreasonable.
> 
> I was thinking some more about overloading `append()` just to see if I missed something in rejecting it and I'm not sure that it really works apart from the issues already identified. In particular when you pass multiple arguments to `append()` the complexity is increased pretty rapidly and you would definitely get different mutation records if you attempted to handle that as multiple moves or some such. Which you would not always be able to do and thus you'd need careful bookkeeping as well. Seems way too messy compared with "new primitive, new method".

Yea that's what we saw in the prototype, the only way to make this not explode in complexity is if *all* the items you append are moveable (already connected to this document)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org

Ah, that doesn't sound unreasonable.

I was thinking some more about overloading append() just to see if I missed something in rejecting it and I'm not sure that it really works apart from the issues already identified. In particular when you pass multiple arguments to append() the complexity is increased pretty rapidly and you would definitely get different mutation records if you attempted to handle that as multiple moves or some such. Which you would not always be able to do and thus you'd need careful bookkeeping as well. Seems way too messy compared with "new primitive, new method".

Yea that's what we saw in the prototype, the only way to make this not explode in complexity is if all the items you append are moveable (already connected to this document)

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: discussing a bit with smaug this morning we think that it should prolly be `connectedMoveCallback` to match the existing pattern of only firing for connected/disconnected cases and not say, for a move within a disconnected subtree
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: discussing a bit with smaug this morning we think that it should prolly be connectedMoveCallback to match the existing pattern of only firing for connected/disconnected cases and not say, for a move within a disconnected subtree

content.body: And you'd want oldAncestor (which can be your parent if you are being moved) and newAncestor (which can be your parent if you are being moved) as arguments.
But the specification-level hook should be more generic and match the existing remove/insert pattern.
Richard Gibson: thanks for sharing those IPv6 tidbits, that's terrible ðŸ˜…
content.formatted_body: Richard Gibson: thanks for sharing those IPv6 tidbits, that's terrible ðŸ˜…

content.body: I've no idea how we could generically handle a network deciding on some prefix. Though maybe we have that information when we do DNS resolving? Hmm.
annevk: I didn't understand "move within a disconnected subtree". You can't call `moveBefore` inside a disconnected subtree
content.formatted_body: annevk: I didn't understand "move within a disconnected subtree". You can't call moveBefore inside a disconnected subtree

content.body: You move the whole subtree
Noam Rosenthal: oh, we have an is connected precondition? Fair.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: oh, we have an is connected precondition? Fair.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Noam Rosenthal: discussing a bit with smaug this morning we think that it should prolly be `connectedMoveCallback` to match the existing pattern of only firing for connected/disconnected cases and not say, for a move within a disconnected subtree

Do you mean not firing `disconnectedCallback` at all when you're moved? I want to make sure this doesn't break CEs that don't expect being reparented without those callbacks
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Noam Rosenthal: discussing a bit with smaug this morning we think that it should prolly be connectedMoveCallback to match the existing pattern of only firing for connected/disconnected cases and not say, for a move within a disconnected subtree
Do you mean not firing disconnectedCallback at all when you're moved? I want to make sure this doesn't break CEs that don't expect being reparented without those callbacks

content.body: and in disconnected case there would be no callbacks at all

> <@annevk:matrix.org> Noam Rosenthal: oh, we have an is connected precondition? Fair.

Yes, everything has to be connected, and (currently) also in the same tree-scope
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Noam Rosenthal: oh, we have an is connected precondition? Fair.
Yes, everything has to be connected, and (currently) also in the same tree-scope

content.body: If disconnected move is not supported you can ignore that caveat.

> <@smaug:mozilla.org> and in disconnected case there would be no callbacks at all

It would throw an error if you try to move something disconnected
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
and in disconnected case there would be no callbacks at all
It would throw an error if you try to move something disconnected

content.body: I think I'd still argue for the same general design for consistency, even if some cases are not supported (atm).
it would be nonsensical anyway, the iframe etc. is not loaded
It's more a matter of consistency, but it seems totally reasonable to not support disconnected cases for now (and potentially ever).

Noam Rosenthal: Going back to your earlier question. I think the default implementation calling the other callbacks is probably fine. I suspect the main feedback is that it should be called `connectedMoveCallback` to match the existing callback naming and that it should have two arguments.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: Going back to your earlier question. I think the default implementation calling the other callbacks is probably fine. I suspect the main feedback is that it should be called connectedMoveCallback to match the existing callback naming and that it should have two arguments.

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Noam Rosenthal: Going back to your earlier question. I think the default implementation calling the other callbacks is probably fine. I suspect the main feedback is that it should be called `connectedMoveCallback` to match the existing callback naming and that it should have two arguments.

That's SGTM. So `connectedMoveCallback(oldAncestor, newAncestor)` that defaults to `disconnectedCallback(); connectedCallback()`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Noam Rosenthal: Going back to your earlier question. I think the default implementation calling the other callbacks is probably fine. I suspect the main feedback is that it should be called connectedMoveCallback to match the existing callback naming and that it should have two arguments.
That's SGTM. So connectedMoveCallback(oldAncestor, newAncestor) that defaults to disconnectedCallback(); connectedCallback()

content.body: Hmm, smaug do we perhaps only need oldAncestor? It seems like connectedCallback isn't given any argument today. disconnectedCallback isn't either.
content.formatted_body: Hmm, smaug do we perhaps only need oldAncestor? It seems like connectedCallback isn't given any argument today. disconnectedCallback isn't either.

content.body: ah, true, disconnectedCallback doesn't know it. connectedCallback can check the new ancestor tree
`attributeChangedCallback` does, this is perhaps a bit like `ancestorChangedCallback`
content.formatted_body: attributeChangedCallback does, this is perhaps a bit like ancestorChangedCallback

content.body: we could always add it later if needed
So no arguments then. Makes sense.
Yea starting simpler and extending later is reasonable

Just catching up on the moveBefore() stuff (currently in different breakout session). Yeah, I'd prefer sticking with a connected precondition. One question is, do we need a same-tree scope precondition? We've started with this since crossing shadow dom barriers just "seemed" tricky, but i'm not sure there's a real argument for preventing this.
Dominic Farolino: I've been assuming same-shadow-including document. So from my perspective that would be fine/preferred.
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: I've been assuming same-shadow-including document. So from my perspective that would be fine/preferred.

content.body: Or same-shadow-including root that is a document.
annevk: So it sounds like you're OK removing this condition
content.formatted_body: annevk: So it sounds like you're OK removing this condition

content.body: https://whatpr.org/dom/1307.html#dom-node-movebefore:~:text=this%E2%80%99s%20root%20is%20the%20same%20as%20node%E2%80%99s%20root
Or no, not removing it but expanding it to cross the shadow boundary. I think i'm fine with that
